text.7: In this verse, Allah reaffirms His statement in the previous verse by saying to the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) that the polytheists certainly know the manifest deeds that he has carried out. Allah and the Prophet Muhammad know better who deviates from the right path that has been laid out for him, so that they obtain misery in this world and the hereafter. Allah also knows who follows the right path so that they obtain everything they desire, namely happiness in this world and the hereafter. Allah knows the actions of those who deviate from the right path, therefore they will feel misery in this world, such as defeat in wars and the destruction of their beliefs, and in the hereafter they will receive a painful torment.
text.8:
This verse commands the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) to firmly reject all kinds of offers, invitations, and desires from the polytheists of Mecca who refused to listen to the verses of Allah, and even denied them. The Messenger of Allah was forbidden from following them, because they were on a misguided path while he was already on the straight path.

In another verse, Allah says:

And if you obey most of those upon the earth, they will mislead you from the way of Allah. They follow not except assumption, and they are not but falsifying. (al-An'am/6: 116)
text.9:
This verse explains that the polytheists wanted the Messenger of Allah to follow and fulfill their requests, and to allow their invitation for the Messenger of Allah to be lenient towards them. If the Messenger of Allah and the Muslims were willing to be lenient towards them, then they would also be lenient towards him and the Muslims.

According to a narration, the Quraysh once offered the Messenger of Allah to reduce his da'wah activities and to no longer insult their idols. They were even willing to follow the Prophet's teachings once, as long as after that the Prophet and his followers followed their teachings once, alternating in this way. This invitation was of course rejected by the Prophet because it was not in accordance with the da'wah he brought to abandon polytheism and replace it with the teachings of tawhid.

This invitation began when the Messenger of Allah conveyed the religion of Allah to the polytheists of Mecca openly and with courage, even though at that time the Muslims were in a weak state and the enemy was strong. All the reasons put forward by the Messenger of Allah related to the proof of the truth of his message could not be answered by the polytheists. On the contrary, their answers showed the weakness of the beliefs they adhered to. Therefore, they asked the Messenger of Allah to be lenient towards them and to stop his insults to the idols they worshiped. If the Messenger of Allah (saw) was willing to accept the offer, then they would also be willing to fulfill his desires, such as being lenient towards the Messenger of Allah (saw) and the Muslims. They were also willing to worship Allah while still being allowed to worship their gods and carry out the customs of their ancestors. They were also willing to find a wife that the Prophet (saw) liked or collect the wealth he desired.

Based on the desire to alleviate the suffering experienced by his companions due to the torture carried out by the polytheists, it occurred to the Prophet Muhammad to be lenient towards the polytheists by accepting some of their offers. Then this verse was revealed, warning the Prophet (saw) never to be lenient towards them, but to remain as usual, namely to take a firm and decisive stance.

This verse is in line with Allah's word:

"And if We had not strengthened you, you would have almost leaned towards them a little. Then We would have made you taste double [punishment] in this life and double after death, and then you would not find for yourself against Us any helper." (al-Isra'/17: 74-75)

If the meaning of this verse is studied, it will be known that there was a specific purpose from the polytheists, which the Messenger of Allah should not know, in putting forward their offer to him. They wanted to deceive the Messenger of Allah (saw) with that invitation, where if accepted, the newly conveyed religion of Islam would be mixed with elements of shirk. There would be mutual influence between the two types of beliefs, so that the religion of Islam would no longer have a pure akidah of tawhid.

Allah's rebuke to the Messenger of Allah (saw) is also a rebuke to all Muslims, so that they are careful in matters of akidah. Never include elements of shirk in the Islamic akidah, even a little.
text.10:
In these verses, Allah reminds and commands Prophet Muhammad to:

1. Not follow the desires of those who readily take oaths, because those who like to swear are only liars. And lying is the root of evil and the source of all kinds of immoral acts. Therefore, Islam states that lying is one of the signs of a hypocrite. Prophet Muhammad said, as narrated by al-Bukhari: "The signs of a hypocrite are three: when he speaks, he lies; when he is entrusted, he betrays; and when he promises, he does not fulfill his promise." (Narrated by al-Bukhari, Muslim, at-Tirmidhi, and an-Nasa'i from Abu Hurairah)

A person who likes to swear is not a good person. A person who does not have good thoughts and intentions towards others suspects that others are the same towards him. Therefore, to convince others of his truthfulness, he swears.

2. Not follow those who are of lowly and misleading thoughts, such as invitations to follow their religion in some matters.

3. Not follow those who always slander others, and mention the bad things about others, whether directly or indirectly.

4. Not follow those who like to slander, such as influencing people to dislike someone else, and trying to create chaos. Allah states that slander with the meaning of chaos is greater in its consequences than murder.

And kill them wherever you overtake them and expel them from wherever they have expelled you. And fitnah is worse than killing. (al-Baqarah/2: 191)

5. Not follow those who like to forbid good deeds and prevent others from doing good, or they themselves do not like to do good.

6. Not follow those who are accustomed to committing transgressions, such as those who like to violate Allah's commands and do not stop the acts that He has forbidden. Allah says:

And whoever disobeys Allah and His Messenger and transgresses His limits - He will put him into the Fire to abide eternally therein, and he will have a humiliating punishment. (an-Nisa'/4: 14)

7. Not follow those who are accustomed to committing sins and immoral acts because they are people who have no self-respect and good morals. Sinful acts will eliminate self-respect and are contrary to noble morals. Allah does not like those who like to commit sinful acts. He says:

And do not argue on behalf of those who deceive themselves. Indeed, Allah does not like one who is a habitually sinful deceiver. (an-Nisa'/4: 107)

8. Not follow those who like to be cruel and have no compassion. Allah is the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful to His servants. Therefore, cruelty and lack of compassion are contrary to the attributes of Allah. One of the reasons why Islam spread quickly in the Arabian Peninsula was because of Prophet Muhammad's gentle attitude. If he had been harsh and cruel, people would have avoided him. Allah says:

So by mercy from Allah, [O Muhammad], you were lenient with them. And if you had been rude [in speech] and harsh in heart, they would have dispersed from about you. So pardon them and ask forgiveness for them and consult them in the matter. (Ali 'Imran/3: 159)

9. Not follow those whose origins are unknown, namely:

    a. People whose condition is unknown, where they come from, what their job is, what their character is, and so on.

    b. People whose origins are unknown and whose intentions and purposes are unclear, as well as what motives are behind their invitations.

And kill them wherever you overtake them and expel them from wherever they have expelled you. And *al-fitnah* is worse than killing. (al-Baqarah/2: 191)

5. Not follow those who like to forbid good deeds and prevent others from doing good, or they themselves do not like to do good.

6. Not follow those who are accustomed to doing things that are excessive, such as those who like to violate Allah's commands and do not stop the things that He has forbidden. Allah says:

And whoever disobeys Allah and His Messenger and transgresses His limits - He will put him into the Fire to abide eternally therein, and he will have a humiliating punishment. (an-Nisa'/4: 14)

7. Not follow those who are accustomed to doing sinful and immoral acts because they are people who have no self-respect and good morals. Sinful acts will eliminate self-respect and contradict noble morals. Allah does not like those who like to do sinful acts. He says:

And do not argue on behalf of those who deceive themselves. Indeed, Allah does not like one who is a habitually sinful deceiver. (an-Nisa'/4: 107)

8. Not follow those who like to be cruel and have no compassion. Allah is the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful to His servants. Therefore, cruelty and lack of compassion are contrary to the attributes of Allah. One of the reasons why Islam spread quickly in the Arabian Peninsula was because of Prophet Muhammad's gentle attitude. If he had been harsh and cruel, people would have avoided him. Allah says:

So by mercy from Allah, [O Muhammad], you were lenient with them. And if you had been rude [in speech] and harsh in heart, they would have disbanded from about you. So pardon them and ask forgiveness for them and consult them in the matter. (Ali 'Imran/3: 159)

9. Not follow those whose origins are unknown, namely:

    a. People whose condition is unknown, where they come from, what their job is, what their character is, and so on.

    b. People whose origins are unknown and whose intentions and goals are unclear, as well as what motives are behind their invitations.
text.13:
In these verses, Allah reminds and commands Prophet Muhammad to:

1.  Not follow the desires of those who readily take oaths, because those who like to swear are only liars. And lying is the root of evil and the source of all kinds of immoral acts. Therefore, Islam states that lying is one of the signs of a hypocrite. Prophet Muhammad said, as narrated by al-Bukhari: "The signs of a hypocrite are three: when he speaks, he lies; when he is entrusted, he betrays; and when he promises, he does not fulfill his promise." (Narrated by al-Bukhari, Muslim, at-Tirmidhi, and an-Nasa'i from Abu Hurairah)

    A person who likes to swear is not a good person. A person who does not have good thoughts and intentions towards others suspects that others are the same towards him. Therefore, to convince others of his truth, he swears.

2.  Not follow those who are base-minded and misleading, such as invitations to follow their religion in some matters.

3.  Not follow those who always slander others, and mention the bad things about others, whether directly or indirectly.

4.  Not follow those who like to slander, such as influencing people to dislike someone else, and trying to create chaos. Allah states that slander with the meaning of chaos is greater in its consequences than murder.

    "And kill them wherever you overtake them and expel them from wherever they have expelled you, and *al-fitnah* is worse than killing." (al-Baqarah/2: 191)

5.  Not follow those who like to forbid good deeds and prevent others from doing good, or he himself does not like to do good.

6.  Not follow those who are accustomed to doing transgressions, such as those who like to violate Allah's commands and do not stop the acts that He has forbidden. Allah says:

    "And whoever disobeys Allah and His Messenger and transgresses His limits - He will put him into the Fire to abide eternally therein, and he will have a humiliating punishment." (an-Nisa'/4: 14)

7.  Not follow those who are accustomed to doing sins and immoral acts because he is a person who has no self-respect and good morals. Sinful acts will eliminate self-respect and are contrary to noble morals. Allah does not like those who like to do sinful acts. He says:

    "And do not argue on behalf of those who deceive themselves. Indeed, Allah does not like one who is a habitually sinful deceiver." (an-Nisa'/4: 107)

8.  Not follow those who like to be cruel and have no compassion. Allah is the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful to His servants. Therefore, the nature of cruelty and having no compassion is contrary to the attributes of Allah. One of the reasons why Islam spread quickly in the Arabian Peninsula was because of Prophet Muhammad's gentle attitude. If he had been harsh and cruel, people would have avoided him. Allah says:

9.  Not follow those whose origins are unknown, namely:

    1.  People whose circumstances are unknown, where they come from, what their work is, what their character is, and so on.

    2.  People whose origins are unknown and whose intentions and purposes are unclear, as well as what motives are behind their invitations.
text.14:
In this verse, Allah warns Prophet Muhammad and the Muslims never to follow those who possess the aforementioned characteristics, even if they possess abundant wealth, high status, great power, or experience temporary worldly pleasures and enjoyments. All of that will be of no benefit in the sight of Allah on the Day of Judgment. Allah says:

"Leave Me with the one I created alone, and granted him extensive wealth, and children attending [upon him], and spread [everything] before him far and wide. Then he desires that I should increase [it]. No! Indeed, he has been obstinate toward Our verses (Al-Qur'an). I will burden him with a mount of torment. Indeed, he thought and deliberated, so may he be killed! How he deliberated! Then may he be killed! How he deliberated! Then he looked, then frowned and scowled, then turned back and was arrogant." (al-Muddatstsir/74: 11-23)
text.15:
This verse explains that when the polytheists of Mecca listened to the recitation of the verses of the Qur'an, they said that the Qur'an was nothing more than the words of Muhammad and contained tales of ancient people, not at all a revelation conveyed to him by Allah. In another verse, Allah says:

"Then he said, 'This is nothing but magic learned [from others]. This is nothing but the word of a human being.'" (al-Muddatstsir/74: 24-25)

Besides, the polytheists also said that the Qur'an was magic presented by a magician and so on. However, from all the accusations they hurled, it can be understood that they did so solely because they had lost their minds in searching for reasons that could be put forward to refute the truth of the Qur'an. Every time they pondered it, more and more belief arose in their hearts towards the Qur'an. Nevertheless, their desires still overcame the truth that had arisen in the depths of their hearts.
text.16: In this verse, Allah affirms that they are truly misguided people, and He will make them humiliated in the world. To manifest their humiliation, Allah will place a mark on their noses like an elephant's trunk, so that everyone knows their true state. The meaning of placing a mark on their noses is so that everyone knows that they are evil people and full of sin, making them easily recognizable.
text.17:
This verse explains that Allah has bestowed upon the polytheists of Mecca numerous blessings in the form of worldly pleasures and luxuries. All of this is intended to see whether they will be grateful for the greater blessings given by giving out the rights of the poor, accepting the call of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to follow the right path, and submitting and obeying Allah, or whether, with these blessings, they want to accumulate wealth, challenge the call of the Prophet, and deviate from the right path? Allah will inflict a painful punishment upon them and eliminate those blessings if they remain in disbelief, as happened to some garden owners.

The owner of the garden was originally a righteous man, obedient, and compliant in carrying out Allah's commands and avoiding all His prohibitions. He had a plot of land as his source of livelihood. When he was about to harvest the produce of his garden, he would inform the poor and needy to come to his garden, and directly give them their rights from the produce of the garden. After he died, the garden was inherited by their children. When they were about to harvest the produce, they consulted whether to continue doing what their father had done or to make a new plan. One of them suggested that they continue doing what their father used to do, namely, informing the poor and needy to come on the day of harvest.

However, this proposal was rejected by his other siblings. They did not want to give even a little of the garden's produce to the poor and needy as their father had done. Even though they were reminded by one of the siblings about the danger that might befall them, they remained with the decision to harvest the produce of the garden without informing the poor and needy beforehand, and they would own all the produce of the garden themselves without giving out the rights of others that were in it.

The heirs of the garden owner denied the provisions that their father used to do when he was alive, after seeing the fertility of the plants and the abundance of fruit to be harvested. They were also sure that all of it would surely become their property. Therefore, they swore to harvest it very early in the morning so that no one would know. They also agreed not to give the produce of the garden to anyone, even a little.

text.19: Allah's decree and will are certain to occur, and no one can prevent them. So, during the night, by Allah's decree and will, lightning struck and burned their entire garden. Not a single thing remained; everything was burned to ashes. This event occurred while the garden owners were sound asleep, so no one knew that their garden had been completely burned. They were negligent and did not remember Allah, the Lord who provides for them.
text.20: Allah's decree and will are certain to occur, and no one can prevent them. So, during the night, by Allah's decree and will, lightning struck and burned their entire garden. Not a single thing remained; everything was burned to ashes. This event occurred while the garden owners were sound asleep, so no one knew that their garden had been completely burned. They were negligent and did not remember Allah, the Lord who provides them with sustenance.
text.21: After waking up in the morning, they called out to each other and invited each other to go to the garden to harvest its produce. After gathering, they set off and walked secretly, whispering among themselves, "Do not let any of the poor people come to our garden like they used to when our father was still alive. Let all the harvest of this garden be used for our own needs." They went to the garden very early in the morning with the intention that the poor people would not enter their garden, and they were very confident that they would be able to harvest all the produce of the garden.

After gathering, they set off and walked stealthily, whispering amongst themselves, "Do not let any of the poor people come to our garden as they used to when our father was still alive. They went to the garden very early in the morning with the intention that the poor people would not enter their garden, and they were very confident that they would be able to harvest the entire produce of the garden.
text.26: Upon arriving at the garden, they were astonished because the garden had been destroyed and completely burned. They thought that what had burned was not their garden, because their garden, which was filled with lush plants and abundant fruit, was ready to be harvested.
text.27: Finally, they realized and were certain that what was burned was indeed their garden, and they said, "We are not misguided to another garden, this is indeed ours. Because we have sinned by not following what our father had prescribed for every harvest, Allah has destroyed this garden."
text.28: One of them, who had warned them previously, said, "Did I not advise you before that we should all do what our father used to do, which is to always glorify God and sanctify Him, to always be grateful for every blessing He has bestowed upon us by giving a portion of the yield to those who deserve it, and to always pray to Him that we may always be blessed with His grace and bounty? But you all paid no attention to my advice whatsoever."
text.29: They acknowledged their errors and mistakes by stating that Allah destroyed the garden not because of His injustice towards them, but because they themselves had wronged themselves by not giving the rights of the poor and needy.
text.30: They then blamed each other, saying, "It was you who encouraged us to stop giving the rights of the disbelievers and the poor that our father used to give."
text.31:
After blaming each other, they finally regretted their own actions. They then realized that their actions and attitudes had invited such a fate. They said, "Indeed, we are the ones who are at fault. We have violated the lines that Allah has established by not giving the rights of the poor and needy that are in our wealth. Hopefully, Allah will grant us a garden better than the one that has been destroyed. We will truly repent, submit, and obey His commands and avoid all His prohibitions. May Allah grant what is good and beneficial for the life of this world and the life of the Hereafter."

According to a narration from Mujahid, after they repented, Allah granted them a garden better than their destroyed garden and answered their prayers.
text.32:
After blaming each other, they finally regretted their own actions. They then realized that their actions and attitudes had invited such a fate. They said, "Indeed, we are the ones who are at fault. We have violated the boundaries that Allah has set by not giving the rights of the poor and needy that are in our wealth. Hopefully, Allah will bestow upon us a garden better than the one that has been destroyed. We will truly repent, submit, and obey His commands and avoid all His prohibitions. May Allah bestow what is good and beneficial for the life of this world and the life of the Hereafter."

According to a narration from Mujahid, after they repented, Allah bestowed upon them a garden better than their destroyed garden and answered their prayers.
text.33:
Thus was the calamity that Allah inflicted upon the owners of the garden as a trial for them. The trial was very beneficial, so they repented and regretted the deeds that Allah had forbidden. They also promised not to repeat those deeds again, and to remain obedient to Allah and not to commit other forbidden acts. Because they truly repented, Allah granted their prayers and gave them happiness in this world and the hereafter.

What about the polytheists of Mecca, will they continue to behave and act as they have done towards the Prophet Muhammad and the Muslims? If they heed the call of the Prophet Muhammad, surely Allah will give them as He has given to the owners of the garden. Conversely, if they persist in their stance, they will not only receive punishment in this world, but will also receive punishment in the hereafter.

Indeed, the punishment of the hereafter is more severe and heavier than the punishment of this world. If the punishment of the world is only in the form of loss of wealth and pleasure, then the punishment of the hereafter is even more terrible than that, namely a punishment that causes misery and calamity for the physical and spiritual well-being of the person who experiences it.
text.34: This verse affirms that the believers who carry out Allah's commands, avoid His prohibitions, and are submissive and obedient to Him, will be placed in Paradise full of delights in the afterlife. This is as a reward for their faith in Allah and their righteous deeds when they lived in the world.
text.35:
According to Muqatil, when verse 34 above was revealed, the disbelievers of Mecca said to the Muslims, "Indeed, Allah has favored us over you in this worldly life. Therefore, inevitably, we will be favored over you in the Hereafter, or at the very least, be equal to you all." So Allah refuted the statement of those disbelievers with this verse by saying, "Shall We violate Our promises by equating those who submit, are obedient, and devoted to Us with those who commit sins and are always ungrateful to Us?"

Allah's word:

Not equal are the companions of the Fire and the companions of Paradise. The companions of Paradise - they are the attainers [of success]. (al-hasyr/59: 20)

From the words of these disbelievers, it can be understood that according to them, life in this world is a reflection of life in the Hereafter. If someone in this worldly life is granted abundant wealth, power, position, pleasure, and luxury, then surely in the Hereafter they will be the same. Conversely, if someone's worldly life experiences misery and suffering, then surely in the Hereafter they will also be miserable and suffer.

The assumption of those disbelievers is a mistaken assumption. Life in this world is a preparation for life in the Hereafter. If someone's worship and deeds are good, even if they are not granted abundant wealth, power, position, and so on, then they will still receive manifold rewards from Allah. Conversely, if they are ungrateful and commit sinful deeds, even if they obtain abundant wealth, position, and power, then in the Hereafter a place full of misery and humiliation will be prepared for them.
text.36: In this verse, Allah declares the strangeness of the way of thinking of the disbelievers in establishing such a thing. It is as if they do not use correct consideration, sound reason, and fair judgment. Is it possible that the one who is astray is the same as the one who is righteous, the one who is pious with the one who is sinful, the one who is God-fearing with the one who denies Him, and so on. The way of thinking used by the disbelievers is a wrong way of thinking and is influenced by Satan who always misleads mankind.
text.37:
In this verse, it is stated that the opinions or ways of thinking of the disbelievers are not based on revelation from Allah. There is not a single one of Allah's books that explains such a thing. The statement is thrown at them in the form of a question, "Do you, O disbelievers, have a book revealed from the heavens, which you received from your ancestors and then studied from generation to generation, containing a provision like what you say? Do you have such a book that allows you to choose what you want according to your desires?"

This verse is presented in the form of a question. Usually, a question is intended to ask about something unknown, but the question here is to deny and state the ugliness of an action. It is as if Allah is stating to the disbelievers that there is not a single one of His revelations that states such a thing. Their words are words that they have fabricated, and such fabrication is an unpraiseworthy way.
text.38:
In this verse, it is stated that the opinions or ways of thinking of the disbelievers are not based on revelation from Allah. There is not a single book of Allah that explains such a thing. The statement is thrown at them in the form of a question, "Do you, O disbelievers, have a book revealed from the heavens, which you received from your ancestors and then studied from generation to generation, containing a provision like what you say? Do you have such a book that allows you to choose what you want according to your will?"

This verse is presented in the form of a question. Usually, a question is intended to ask about something unknown, but the question here is to deny and state the ugliness of an action. It is as if Allah is stating to the disbelievers that there is not a single revelation of His that states such a thing. Their words are words that they have fabricated, and such a way of fabrication is a way that is not praiseworthy.
text.39: In this verse, Allah once again mocks the disbelievers by posing a rhetorical question, "O disbelievers, have you ever received promises from Us that We must fulfill as you say, namely that you will obtain everything you desire, even though you deny Us?" From this question, it can be understood that Allah has never established or promised His servants such things as they claim.
text.40:
Then Allah commanded His Messenger to ask the disbelievers, with the intention of rebuking their practices, "O disbelievers, if you have a book that explains what you say, show it to us. If it is true that Allah has promised you, established with an oath, that you will obtain everything you desire, try to prove that oath. If you have someone who can guarantee the truth of your words, try to show us that person."

The Prophet's questions and requests to the disbelievers caused them to fall silent, because they would not be able to answer and fulfill those requests. In reality, they worship idols or statues. They made these statues and idols themselves, and they knew that the statues and idols would not be able to guarantee what they said, as if they were powerless to defend their opinions.

The word *za'im* (something responsible) found at the end of this verse means someone who guarantees that something will definitely be realized and is full of truth. If someone says something or promises something, then a *za'im* guarantees that the person's words are true, or that the promise that has been promised will definitely be fulfilled. The disbelievers of Mecca were asked to present who would guarantee the truth of their words, saying that Allah equates the reward received by the believers with the reward they receive, even though Allah never said such a thing.
text.41:
In this verse, the Prophet Muhammad is again commanded to ask the disbelievers whether they have partners who can guarantee the truth of the words they utter. If so, let them try to present or bring them forth to prove their guarantee.

The "partners" referred to in this verse are all those they worship besides Allah, such as the idols Lata, 'Uzza, Manah, and so on. This also includes the people they respect and their religious leaders.

With this final question, the disbelievers of Mecca became even more silent and speechless because it turned out that the gods they worshipped besides Allah, their famous literary figures, such as al-Walid bin al-Mugirah, and others, were unable to present or bring them forth.
text.42: This verse states to the disbelievers of Mecca that if they have a guarantor for the truth of their words, that they will surely enter Paradise just as the believers enter Paradise, then let them bring that witness or guarantor later on the Day of Judgment. On that day, everyone will be in a state of fear and trying to escape from that fear. On that day, they will be asked to prostrate to test their faith, even though they will no longer be able to prostrate, because the joints of their bones will have become weak, because punishment will have enveloped them from above and below, as well as from the right and left sides. A day like that will surely come, and the chaos as intended will surely occur. At that time, there will be no place of refuge except Allah, the Almighty Lord.
text.43:
This verse explains that on the Day of Judgment, the disbelievers will be in a state of utter helplessness. There will be no one to give them assistance, and they will be in a state of humiliation. They will only be filled with regret, but all of that will be of no use anymore.

When they were alive in the world, they were healthy, prosperous, powerful, and held high positions, but they were unwilling to pray (salat), prostrate (sujud), and worship Allah, and submit themselves to Him. After the Hereafter, when the time of regret arrives, they will call upon the Lord, wanting to do it to devote themselves to Him, but they will no longer be able to do it. This is because, in addition to their bones having become weak, the door of repentance has also been closed. Only the believers will be able to prostrate in the Hereafter when Allah reveals Himself to them.
text.44:
This verse is a balm for the heart and a comfort to the Prophet Muhammad, and a stern warning to the disbelievers. The disbelievers displayed a multitude of attitudes and actions towards the Prophet Muhammad and the Muslims in carrying out the task that Allah had entrusted to them. Among these were obstructing people from entering Islam, torturing the Prophet's companions who had embraced Islam, hurting, mocking, boycotting, and isolating the Prophet, and so on. Therefore, the Prophet sometimes felt inclined to pray that Allah would punish and torment those who disbelieved, as had been inflicted upon previous communities. With this verse, Allah states that He knows all forms of attitudes and actions of the disbelievers, and will punish them according to what they have done.

Furthermore, Allah states that because of denying the Qur'an and disbelieving in Allah, the disbelievers are given the opportunity to commit sinful deeds and perpetrate oppression, so that the sinful deeds they commit increase in number. Thus, the recompense of punishment becomes even more severe, so that they cannot bear it. They assume that with the rank, wealth, and power they possess, Allah has bestowed upon them unparalleled grace, but this is not the case. In fact, with the rank, wealth, and power they possess, their sins become even greater. In another verse, Allah says:

"So leave them in their heedlessness for a time. Do they think that what We extend to them of wealth and children is because We hasten unto them with good things? Nay, but they perceive not." (al-Mu'minun/23: 54-56)

Another saying of Allah:

"So when they forgot that with which they had been reminded, We opened to them the gates of all things, until, when they rejoiced in that which they were given, We seized them suddenly, and they were thereupon in despair." (al-An'am/6: 44)
text.45:
Allah states that He gives respite to the disbelievers until an appointed time by allowing them to increase in their disbelief and oppression. Allah also states that His plan cannot be thwarted by anyone, and it will certainly be fulfilled; no one can hinder Him.

In reality, if the disbelievers were to realize, they would certainly arrive at the understanding and view that what they use to obstruct the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) and the believers from establishing the religion of Allah are the blessings that Allah has bestowed upon them, such as wealth, rank, position, and so on. They should have used these blessings to seek His pleasure. Their sin is very great because they deny and misuse Allah's blessings.

Regarding the punishment inflicted upon these disbelievers, it is explained in a hadith of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim:

"Indeed, Allah Ta'ala will postpone the punishment for the oppressors, until when He punishes them, no one will escape that punishment." Then the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) recited (Surah Hud/11: 102): "And such is the seizure of your Lord when He seizes the cities while they are committing wrong. Indeed, His seizure is painful and severe." (Narrated by al-Bukhari, Muslim, Abu Ya'la, al-Baihaqi and an-Nasa'i from Abu Musa al-Asy'ari)
text.46: In this verse, Allah poses a question to the Messenger (saw) with the intention of probing the mindset of the disbelievers, who believe that a person only does something in the hope of a reward, profit, or worldly pleasure. According to them, no one is willing to work and strive solely for the sake of Allah. Allah's question is: O Muhammad, do you ask a reward from those who associate partners with Me, because you advise them, call them to the truth, and to follow My religion, so that they must be burdened by debt because of the reward you ask?
text.47:
In this verse, the question is still continued: Do they have knowledge of the unseen (ghaib), or do they possess something like the Lauh Mahfudh that records everything according to their desires, which would be proof of the truth of their opinion?

The disbelievers of Mecca assumed that the idols they worshipped could tell them everything that would happen and everything that is unseen (ghaib). However, there is absolutely no proof for their assumption.
text.48:
Allah commanded Prophet Muhammad to be patient in accepting His decrees, to continue carrying out the duties of apostleship that had been entrusted to him, and to avoid anything that could hinder or disrupt his efforts in carrying out those duties. Then Allah warned him not to act and behave like someone who was in the belly of a fish, namely Prophet Yunus (Jonah). Because he was angry with his people, Prophet Yunus then left them and prayed to Allah that they be afflicted with a devastating punishment.

This story begins when Prophet Yunus was sent by Allah to the people of the city of Nineveh. He called his people to worship Allah, the One and Only God, there is no god but Him. But the people of the city of Nineveh rejected the invitation, even denying and threatening him. Because of the attitude and actions of his people, he was angry and warned them that Allah would inflict a terrible disaster as a reward for their attitude and denial. He then left his people.

After Prophet Yunus left, his people realized and feared Allah's threat, so they went out of their houses to an open field with their wives, children, and livestock. In the open field, they together declared repentance to Allah, and humbled themselves with full faith. They promised Allah that they would follow Yunus' call, carry out His commands and stop His prohibitions. Because Yunus' people repented sincerely, submitted, and surrendered to Him, Allah granted their prayer by postponing the coming of the disaster to them, as explained in Allah's word:

"Then why was there not a [single] city that believed so its faith benefited it - except the people of Jonah? When they believed, We removed from them the punishment of disgrace in worldly life and gave them enjoyment for a time." (Yunus/10: 98)

As for Prophet Yunus, after giving the warning, he left his people, abandoning the task entrusted to him by Allah as His messenger. Without obtaining permission from Allah, he left on a ship laden with cargo. After the ship sailed and was in the middle of the ocean, the captain became worried that the ship would sink if its cargo was not reduced.

To reduce the ship's cargo, they held a lottery among the passengers. Whoever lost the lottery would be thrown into the sea. In this way, the ship would be saved from the danger of sinking. In the lottery, Prophet Yunus lost, but the ship's passengers felt reluctant to carry out the decision. This was repeated three times and the result was the same, Prophet Yunus still lost. But as with the first time, the passengers also felt reluctant to carry out the decision. Finally, Prophet Yunus made his own decision, and he jumped into the sea. After Yunus jumped into the sea, Allah commanded a large shark to swallow him. The fish was revealed to not eat Yunus' flesh and bones, but simply to make its stomach a prison for Yunus, because Yunus was not its food.

Prophet Yunus felt miserable and wretched in the dark belly of the fish. He repented, prayed, and surrendered himself to Allah, hoping that Allah would forgive his sins and save him, as explained in another of Allah's words:

"And [mention] the man of the fish, when he went away in anger and thought that We would not decree [anything] upon him. And he called out within the darknesses, "There is no deity except You; exalted are You. Indeed, I have been of the wrongdoers." So We responded to him and saved him from the distress. And thus do We save the believers." (al-Anbiya'/21: 87-88)
text.49:
After several days in the belly of the fish, Prophet Yunus was showered with mercy by Allah, who inspired the fish to cast Yunus onto the land. So the fish cast Yunus onto the land. He fell on barren land, desolate with no water, vegetation, or trees around. His body was in a very weak and sick state, due to the suffering he had experienced while in the belly of the fish, and because of his sadness due to the attitude of his people who challenged his da'wah. To protect him from the scorching heat of the sun and the cold of the night, Allah grew beside him a kind of gourd tree (yaqthin). Thus, Prophet Yunus was protected and could also eat its fruit to strengthen his weak body, as Allah says:

"Then We cast him onto the open shore while he was ill. And We caused to grow over him a gourd vine." (as-saffat/37: 145-146)

If Allah had not bestowed His mercy upon Yunus, he would have certainly drowned in the sea, or been crushed to pieces in the belly of the fish, or died of hunger and thirst in the middle of the barren desert. However, Allah is Most Merciful to His servants who repent sincerely, as Prophet Yunus did. Therefore, Allah bestowed mercy upon him.
text.50:
After Yunus' health recovered, as did his physical strength, Allah sent him back to his people, who at that time numbered one hundred thousand or more, as Allah says:

"And We sent him to [a population of] a hundred thousand or more. And they believed, so We gave them enjoyment for a time." (as-Saffat/37: 147-148)

Yunus' arrival was greeted with joy by his people, and they declared their faith in him, so they became among the righteous.

With the verses above, Allah warns the Prophet Muhammad not to behave and act like the Prophet Yunus, who was easily angered and easily despaired, so that he left his people and the sacred task that had been entrusted to him, namely the task of prophethood. The Prophet Muhammad was commanded to always be steadfast and patient in any situation because Allah loves those who are patient.
text.51:
Allah declares to Prophet Muhammad saw that because the polytheists were very angry and hateful towards him, they looked at the Prophet from the corner of their eyes with gazes full of anger and hatred. This was especially so whenever they heard the recitation of the verses of the Al-Qur'an.

According to some Quranic commentators (mufassirun), what is meant by "those who almost made the Prophet slip with their gazes" were the Bani Asad, one of the tribes in the land of Arabia at that time. It is narrated that the people of Bani Asad possessed a kind of knowledge that could influence others by using the sharpness of their gaze. So some of them intended to try their knowledge on Prophet Muhammad, because according to them, if Muhammad was truly a messenger sent by Allah, then he would not be affected by their knowledge. The reality was that this knowledge was indeed ineffective against the Messenger of Allah saw.

From the above narration, this verse is understood to mean that all kinds of occult knowledge will not be able to affect or influence a person if he believes in Allah, except for knowledge that is in accordance with *sunnatullah* (the laws of Allah), such as hurting someone by influencing their soul in accordance with the evidence and stipulations of psychology, torturing someone with electric current, and so on. Such knowledge can influence a person.

Because the polytheists could not influence the Messenger of Allah with the knowledge they possessed, such as the sharpness of their gaze, and because they could not match the verses of the Al-Qur'an, they said that he (Muhammad) was indeed a madman.
text.52:
In this verse, Allah states firmly that the Qur'an contains guidance and lessons for the happiness of human life in this world and the hereafter. It is intended for all people wherever they are, whether for the inhabitants of advanced countries or for the inhabitants of developing or backward countries, whether for the intelligent or for the ignorant, whether city dwellers or villagers, whether for the rich or for the poor, and so on. Therefore, everyone can learn to understand and study the Qur'an, as long as they have an attitude of accepting every truth conveyed to them. If someone does not yet have such an attitude, even though their heart and mind have accepted the truth of the Qur'an, their desires (hawa nafsu) command them to oppose the Qur'an and say that it is made by humans or other accusations.

How many people constantly fight against truth and justice because they indulge their desires (hawa nafsu), such as the desire for rank, position, abundant wealth, fear of being ostracized by their group, fear of abandoning the beliefs of their ancestors, and so on. How many people are willing to kill friends, siblings, even their father and mother because they follow their desires (hawa nafsu).

Muhammad saw is a prophet and messenger of Allah whose honesty has been proven, a person respected and trusted by his people, perfectly just in his mind, no one denies him. After Allah appointed him as a prophet and messenger, hatred arose, because following Muhammad saw meant abandoning rank, wealth, pleasure, and arbitrariness.
